data.content:
n = int(input().strip())
coins = list(map(int, input().strip().split(" ")))
dp = [0]*(n+1)

for i in range(1, n+1):
    dp[i] = max(dp[i-1], dp[i-1]+coins[i-1])

print(max(dp))

prompt:
Fix a buggy program written in Ruby language to solve the following programming problem:
Description: Iahub got bored, so he invented a game to be played on paper. He writes n integers a1, a2, ..., an. Each of those integers can be either 0 or 1. He's allowed to do exactly one move: he chooses two indices i and j (1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ n) and flips all values ak for which their positions are in range [i, j] (that is i ≤ k ≤ j). Flip the value of x means to apply operation x = 1 - x.The goal of the game is that after exactly one move to obtain the maximum number of ones. Write a program to solve the little game of Iahub.
Input Specification: The first line of the input contains an integer n (1 ≤ n ≤ 100). In the second line of the input there are n integers: a1, a2, ..., an. It is guaranteed that each of those n values is either 0 or 1.
Output Specification: Print an integer — the maximal number of 1s that can be obtained after exactly one move. 

Sample Input:
5
1 0 0 1 0
Sample Output:
4

Sample Input:
4
1 0 0 1
Sample Output:
4

Notes: NoteIn the first case, flip the segment from 2 to 5 (i = 2, j = 5). That flip changes the sequence, it becomes: [1 1 1 0 1]. So, it contains four ones. There is no way to make the whole sequence equal to [1 1 1 1 1].In the second case, flipping only the second and the third element (i = 2, j = 3) will turn all numbers into 1.
Take input from standard input and output to standard output

Here is the code with a bug of WRONG_ANSWER:

n = gets.strip.to_i
coins = gets.strip.split(" ").map(&:to_i)
current_max_ones = 0
number_of_flipped_element = 0
i = 0 
current_flipped_ones = 0
number_of_ones = coins.count(1)
i0 = 0
j0 = 0
# p coins
number_of_ones_before = 0
number_of_ones_after = number_of_ones
while i < n do
  # puts i
  if coins[i] == 0 then
    if current_flipped_ones == 0 then
      i0 = i
      number_of_ones_before = coins[0..i0].count(1)
      # number_of_ones_after = number_of_ones - number_of_ones_before
    end
    current_flipped_ones += 1
    # puts "number_of_ones_before: #{number_of_ones_before}, number_of_ones_after: #{number_of_ones_after}, 
    #   current_flipped_ones: #{current_flipped_ones}"
    current_max_ones = current_max_ones >= number_of_ones_before + current_flipped_ones + number_of_ones_after ? 
        current_max_ones : number_of_ones_before + current_flipped_ones + number_of_ones_after
  else
    if current_flipped_ones == 0 then
      number_of_ones_before += 1
      # puts "here"
      # puts i
    end
      # current_flipped_ones -= 1
      number_of_ones_after -= 1
      current_max_ones = current_max_ones >= number_of_ones_before + current_flipped_ones + number_of_ones_after ? 
        current_max_ones : number_of_ones_before + current_flipped_ones + number_of_ones_after
      if current_flipped_ones == i - i0 + 1 - current_flipped_ones then
        current_flipped_ones = 0
      end
  end
  # puts "#{i} iteration: current_max_ones: #{current_max_ones}"
  i += 1
end
# puts "something"
# number_of_flipped_element = number_of_flipped_element == 0 ? 1 : number_of_flipped_element
# puts number_of_flipped_element
# puts current_max_flipped_ones
puts current_max_ones
# puts coins.count(1) - (number_of_flipped_element - current_max_flipped_ones) + current_max_flipped_ones

Provide the fixed Ruby code without any description or extra tokens.

Fixed source code:
